Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Searches for New Fundamental Symmetries at the Energy Frontier
Award.AbstractNarration: The physics program of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland is in full operation, delivering proton-proton collisions at 7 TeV collision energy. This CAREER program led by Prof Dmitri Tsybychev is focused on the ATLAS experiment and there are three aspects. The first is the study of events containing W + Jets and W + Jets + missing ET in the final state with the objective of measuring the cross section for WL WL scattering at high mass. In the absence of some control at the electroweak scale this cross section becomes unbounded. The Higgs boson is a means to control this, but there may be other new physics at play. The challenge is that the WW cross section is very small and hence high energy and high luminosity are both required. The second aspect of the program is focuses on the upgrade of the ATLAS vertex detectors. At the very high interaction rates expected at the LHC, the highest resolution elements of the inner detector (in this case pixel layers) are fundamental to identifying and disentangling collision vertices, identification of decay vertices of long-lived particles and for the tracking of charged particles. The Tsybychev group is involved in the R&D, design and construction of 3D pixel sensors ? a novel, powerful, and potentially robust technology for inner tracking. The third aspect is the participation of this group in the broader aspects of the MARIACHI project based at Brookhaven National Laboratory and SUNY Stony Brook. Here the excitement of particle physics at the Energy Frontier through the ATLAS experiment and the excitement of studying cosmic rays and the Cosmic Frontier through MARIACHI come together for high school teachers and students on Long Island.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI is collaborating on ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) Geneva, Switzerland. The ATLAS collaboration includes more than 170 institutes and universities from 38 countries around the world, including 44 institutes from USA. The LHC is the energy frontier at 13 TeV center of mass energy, where beams of protons will collide with unprecedented luminosity. The intellectual merit of the research program conducted by the PI is to uncover the mechanism responsible for electroweak symmetry breaking in the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. The discovery of the Higgs boson was made at LHC, which existence was theoretically predicted more than 50 years ago. The studies now our underway to study properties of this new fundamental particle and verify that Higgs field is the sole agent providing electroweak symmetry breaking. Properties of the Higgs boson are well predicted in SM, once the mass is known, among them is the strength of Higgs interactions with fermions, or frequency of decay, is proportional to their masses. PI searched for decay of the Higgs boson to muons, second generation leptons, and limits were placed on the production cross section. The results were in agreement with the prediction from SM. PI studied final states with charged lepton plus jets final state, which may result from production of di bosons, decay of heavier cousins of the SM Higgs boson, through production and decay of heavier beyond the SM gauge bosons or anomalous triple or quartic gauge couplings. While providing exciting prospects for physics discovery, the LHC also provides a very challenging environment for detection of that physics. Thus, the program provided a complementary approach between physics analysis and development of novel type silicon radiation detector for the ATLAS experiment in support of this physics program. As a result a new higher resolution additional layer of pixel detector was installed inside the ATLAS pixel detector, which greatly improved detection of heavy flavor jets and reduced misidentification of light jets as heavy jets. Developments for technologies required for these radiation detectors are another component of intellectual merit. This program will continue as ATLAS plans another detector upgrade in the future to cope with even higher collision rate of the high luminosity LHC running. On broader impact, the program provided unique opportunities to students and postdocs to develop expertise in developing and operating complex detector systems, software and perform physics analyses. The new technical developments also hold the promise for further applications in other scientific disciplines by providing enhanced possibilities for radiation detection.
